claim: Parents share more genes with their child than siblings do.

supporting.text: Parents pass on exactly 50% of their genes to each child, while siblings share on average 50% of their genes due to random recombination.

attacks.text: Parents pass on exactly 50% of their genes to each child, while siblings share on average 50% of their genes due to random recombination.
Identical twins share 100% of their genes, which is more than the 50% shared between parents and children.
Identical twins are a rare exception and do not represent the general case of sibling genetic similarity.
Mitochondrial DNA is inherited exclusively from the mother, meaning children share more than 50% of their genes with their mother when considering this additional genetic material.
Mitochondrial DNA represents a very small fraction of the total genome, so its impact on overall genetic similarity is negligible.
In cases of inbreeding, siblings can share more than 50% of their genes due to shared ancestry from both parents.
Inbreeding is uncommon in most human populations and represents a special case rather than the norm.
